0.792 | blank3_name_sec1 = HDI Category | blank3_info_sec1 = high | blank4_name_sec1 = Literacy | blank4_info_sec1 = 81.9 | website = {{URL|chandigarh.nic.in/}} | footnotes = The city of Chandigarh comprises all of the union territory's area }} '''Chandigarh''', also known as ''The City Beautiful'', is a city and a [[union territory]] in the [[Northern India|northern part]] of [[India]] that serves as the capital of the states of [[Haryana]] and [[Punjab, India|Punjab]]. As a union territory, the city is ruled directly by the [[Government of India|Union Government of India]] and is not part of either state. The city of Chandigarh was the first [[planned city]] in India post-independence in 1947 and is known internationally for its architecture and urban design.[http://business.gov.in/investment_incentives/chandigarh.php Business Portal of India] The master plan of the city was prepared by [[Le Corbusier]], transformed from an earlier plan by the American planner [[Albert Mayer (planner)|Albert Mayer]]. Most of the government buildings and housing in the city, however, were designed by the Chandigarh Capital Project Team headed by [[Pierre Jeanneret]], [[Jane Drew]] and [[Maxwell Fry]]. The city experiences extreme climate and uneven distribution of rainfall. The roads in Chandigarh are surrounded by trees and it has the third highest forest cover in India at 8.51% followed by [[Lakshwadeep]] and [[Goa]].[http://www.walkthroughindia.com/lifestyle/top-10-green-cities-of-india/ "Green Cities of India"][http://www.hindustantimes.com/chandigarh/chandigarh-has-third-highest-tree-cover-in-india/article1-1242800.aspx "Chandigarh has the third highest forest cover"]. [[Hindustan Times]]. The city tops the list of [[States and territories of India|Indian States and Union Territories]] by per capita income in the country.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2008/09/17/stories/2008091755600800.htm |title=Front Page News : Monday, July 26, 2010 |publisher=The Hindu |date= 17 September 2008|accessdate=2010-07-26 |location=Chennai, India}} The city was reported to be the cleanest in India in 2010, based on a national government study,{{cite web|url=http://news.rediff.com/slide-show/2010/may/11/slide-show-1-chandigarh-cleanest-of-all.htm |title=India's cleanest: Where does your city stand?: Rediff.com News |publisher=News.rediff.com |date=13 May 2010 |accessdate=2010-07-26}} and the territory also headed the list of Indian states and territories according to [[Human Development Index]].[http://megplanning.gov.in/MHDR/Human_De.pdf Meghalaya Human Development Report 2008] (p. 23) The metropolitan of Chandigarh-[[Greater Mohali|Mohali]]-[[Panchkula]] collectively forms a Tri-city.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=6 January 2014 India.http://www.who.int/kobe_centre/publications/smokefree_case_study_chandigarh/en/ ==Etymology== The name Chandigarh, meaning "the fort of goddess Chandi",http://www.cii.in/chandigarh is derived from [[Chandi Mandir]], an ancient temple devoted to the [[Hinduism|Hindu]] goddess [[Chandi]], near the city in [[Panchkula]] District.http://www.newkerala.com/states-of-india/chandigarh.php ==History== After the [[partition of India]] in 1947, the [[Punjab Province (British India)|former British province of Punjab]] was also split between [[east Punjab]] in India and [[west Punjab]] in Pakistan.http://www.citybeautiful.in/chandigarhhistory.aspx The Indian Punjab required a new capital city to replace [[Lahore]], which became part of Pakistan during the partition.[http://www.chandigarh.co.uk/history.html Chandigarh History – History Of Chandigarh India – Origin & History of Chandigarh][http://chandigarh.gov.in/knowchd_general.htm The Official Government Website] So, the government carved out Chandigarh of nearly 50 Puadhi speaking villages of the then state of [[East Punjab]], India.{{cite news|title=Displaced for making Chandigarh, their marginalization is still on|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chandigarh/Displaced-for-making-Chandigarh-their-marginalization-is-still-on/articleshow/13136226.cms}} Chandigarh hosts the largest of Le Corbusier's many ''Open Hand'' sculptures, standing 26 metres high. ''[[Open Hand Monument|The Open Hand (La Main Ouverte)]]'' is a recurring motif in Le Corbusier's architecture, a sign for him of "peace and reconciliation. It is open to give and open to receive." It represents what Le Corbusier called the 'Second Machine Age'.[http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=qG-9cwHOcCIC&pg=PA613&lpg=PA613&dq=le+corbusier+%22the+open+hand%22+india+28+feet&source=bl&ots=skcehGAvZf&sig=ThArn1v4m2sl2VRLnLFwzESDiLU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=R_9SUMSCA6Sf0QXJ3oGoAw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=le%20corbusier%20%22the%20open%20hand%22%20india%2028%20feet&f=false ''Frommer's India''] (2010) Pippa de Bruyn, John Wiley & Sons, p613 ISBN 9780470556108 Two of the six monuments planned in the Capitol Complex which has the High Court, the Assembly and the Secretariat, remain incomplete. These include Geometric Hill and Martyrs Memorial; drawings were made, and they were begun in 1956, but they were never completed.{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/capitol-complex-as-le-corbusier-wanted-it/635844/ |title=Capitol Complex, as Le Corbusier wanted it, remains incomplete |publisher=Indian Express |date=2010-06-19 |accessdate=2013-07-02}} On 1 November 1966, the newly formed state of [[Haryana]] was carved out of the eastern portion of Punjab, in order to create Haryana as a majority [[Haryanvi]]-speaking people, while the western portion of Punjab retained a mostly [[Punjabi language]]-speaking majority and remained as the current state of [[Punjab, India|Punjab]]. Chandigarh was located on the border of both states and the states moved to incorporate the city into their respective territories. However, the city of Chandigarh was made into a [[union territory]] to serve as capital of both states.{{cite web|url=http://www.haryana-online.com/History/history_1966-.htm |title=1st November 1966 - Haryana Day - History - Haryana Online - North India |publisher=Haryana Online |date= |accessdate=2013-07-08}} ==Geography and ecology== ===Location=== Chandigarh is located near the foothills of the [[Sivalik]] range of the [[Himalaya]]s in northwest India. It covers an area of approximately 114 km2.http://chandigarh.gov.in/knowchd_general.htm It shares its borders with the states of Haryana and Punjab. The exact cartographic co-ordinates of Chandigarh are {{Coord|30.74|N|76.79|E|}}.[http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IN/5/Chandigarh.html Falling Rain Genomics, Inc – Chandigarh] It has an average elevation of 321 metres (1053 ft). The city, lying in the northern plains, has vast fertile and flat land. It has portions of [[Bhabhar]] in the north east and [[Terai]] in rest of the area.[http://www.bharatonline.com/chandigarh/travel-tips/location.html Chandigarh Geography] The soil of Chandigarh and other geographical elements. {{Geographic location|Centre = Chandigarh |North = [[Baddi]], [[Himachal Pradesh]] |Northeast = [[Kasauli]], [[Himachal Pradesh]] |East = [[Pinjore]], [[Haryana]] |Southeast = [[Panchkula]], [[Haryana]] |South = [[Zirakpur]], [[Haryana]] |Southwest = [[Mohali]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] |West = [[Mohali]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] |Northwest = [[Kharar, Ajitgarh|Kharar]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] }} The surrounding districts are [[Greater Mohali|Mohali]], [[Patiala]] and [[Roopnagar]] in Punjab, [[Panchkula]] and [[Ambala]] in Haryana. The boundary of the state of [[Himachal Pradesh]] is also minutes away from its north border. ===Climate=== {{climate chart |Chandigarh |3.1|16.4|33 |5.3|20.1|39 |10.4|25.4|30 |15.9|31.5|9 |20.1|35.3|28 |22.4|35.6|145 |20.9|31.0|280 |20.3|29.7|308 |18.8|30.1|133 |14.0|28.8|22 |7.5|24.3|9 |3.7|19.1|22 |source=[http://www.worldweather.org/066/c00526.htm World Weather Information Service] |float=right |clear= }} Chandigarh has a [[humid subtropical climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification|Köppen]]: Cwa) characterised by a seasonal rhythm: very hot summers, mild winters, unreliable rainfall and great variation in temperature (−1 °C to 46 °C). The average annual rainfall is [http://chandigarh.nic.in/knowchd_general.htm 1110.7 mm]. The city also receives occasional winter rains from the [[Western Disturbance]] originating over the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. Cold winds usually tend to come from the north near [[Shimla]], capital of Himanchal Pradesh and from the state of [[Jammu and Kashmir]], both of which receive their share of snowfall during wintertime. The city experiences the following seasons and the respective average temperatures: *'''Spring''': The climate remains the most enjoyable part of the year during the spring season (from February-end to early-April). Temperatures vary between (max) 13 °C to 20 °C and (min) 5 °C to 12 °C. *'''Autumn''': In autumn (from September-end to mid November.), the temperature may rise to a maximum of 30 °C. Temperatures usually remain between 10° to 22° in autumn. The minimum temperature is around 6 °C. *'''Summer''': The temperature in summer (from Mid-April to June-end) may rise to 44 °C. The temperatures might sometime rise to 44 °C in mid-June. Temperatures generally vary between 40 to 42 °C. *'''Monsoon''': During monsoon (from early-July to mid-September), Chandigarh receives moderate to heavy rainfall and sometimes heavy to very heavy rainfall (generally during the month of August or September). Usually, the rain bearing monsoon winds blow from south-west/south-east. Mostly, the city receives heavy rain from south (which is mainly a persistent rain) but it generally receives most of its rain during monsoon either from North-west or North-east. Maximum amount of rain received by the city of Chandigarh during monsoon season is 195.5 mm in a single day. *'''Winter''': Winters (November-end to February-end) are mild but it can sometimes get quite chilly in Chandigarh. Average temperatures in the winter remain at (max) 5 °C to 14 °C and (min) -1 °C to 5 °C. Rain usually comes from the west during winters and it is usually a persistent rain for 2–3 days with sometimes hailstorms. Retrieved 29 September 2012. |source 2=Indian Meteorological Department (extremes){{cite web |url=http://www.imdpune.gov.in/Temp_Extremes/histext2010.pdf |title=Extremes of India |publisher=IMD |accessdate=January 23, 2015 }} MyWeather.com (humidity and sun){{cite web |url=http://www.myweather2.com/City-Town/India/Chandigarh/climate-profile.aspx?month=1 |title=Climate profile for Chandigarh |publisher=MyWeather.com |accessdate=January 18, 2015 }} |date=May 2012}} ===Ecosystem=== Most of Chandigarh is covered by dense [[banyan]] and [[eucalyptus]] plantations, while there are some [[chinar tree]]s as well. [[Ashoka tree|Ashoka]], [[Cassia Fistula|cassia]], [[mulberry]] and other trees flourish in the forested ecosystem. The city has forests surrounding that sustain many animal and plant species.http://chandigarh.gov.in/green_suk_wild4.htm [[Deer]], [[Sambar (deer)|sambar]]s, [[barking deer]], parrots, [[woodpecker]]s and [[peacock]]s inhabit the protected forests. [[Sukhna Lake]] hosts a variety of ducks and geese, and attracts migratory birds from parts of Siberia and Japan in the winter season. A parrot sanctuary in the city is home to a variety of bird species. It has popular gardens, e.g. [[Zakir Hussain Rose Garden]], [[Rock Garden of Chandigarh|Rock Garden]], Terraced Garden, Bougainvillea Garden, Shanti Kunj and many others.http://www.ixigo.com/parks-gardens-in-around-near-chandigarh-lp-1138125?view=list&filterKeys=&filterValues=&sort=po&type=Park%20/%20Garden&order=dsc ==Demographics== {{bar box|width = 300px |barwidth = 250px |cellpadding="0" |title=Religion in Chandigarh{{cite web | title = Census of India – Socio-cultural aspects | publisher = Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs | url = http://censusindia.gov.in/Census_Data_2001/Census_Data_Online/Social_and_cultural/Religion.aspx}} |titlebar=#Fcd116 |left1=Religion |right1=Percent |float=left |bars= {{bar percent|[[Hinduism]]|#FF6600|79}} {{bar percent|[[Sikhism]]|#FFFF00|16}} {{bar percent|[[Islam]]|#009000|4}} {{bar percent|Others|#808080|1}} Others include [[Christians]] (0.7%), [[Jainism|Jains]] (0.2%) & [[Buddhists]] (0.1%)}} [[File:Populationchandigarh.png|thumbnail|The Population of Chandigarh over the years.]] {{IndiaCensusPop | title= Chandigarh Population | 1961= 119881 | 1971= 257251 | 1981= 451610 | 1991= 642015 | 2001= 900635 | 2011= 1055450 | estimate= | estyear= | estref= | footnote= source:[[2011 Census of India|Census of India]]{{cite web|url=http://sampark.chd.nic.in/images/State_2006/StatisticalAbstract2004/Areapopulation/area_pop_tab2.1.pdf|title=Census population|work=Census of India|publisher=http://sampark.chd.nic.in|accessdate=2008-06-04|format=PDF}} }} {{As of|2011}} India census, Chandigarh had a population of 1,055,450 making for a density of about 9252 (7900 in 2001) persons per square kilometre.http://www.censusindia.gov.in/{{cite web|url=http://www.ssachd.nic.in/disereport.htm|title=Census observations|work=Census of India|publisher=http://www.ssachd.nic.in}} Males constitute 55% of the population and females 45%. The sex ratio is 818 females for every 1,000 males –which is the lowest in the country,{{citation needed|date=March 2012}} up from 777 in 2001. Chandigarh has an average literacy rate of 86.77%, higher than the national average; with male literacy of 90.81% and female literacy of 81.88%. 10.8% of the population is under 6 years of age. There is a substantial decline in the population growth rate in Chandigarh with just 17.10% growth between 2001-2011. Since, 1951-1961 it has come down from 394.13% to 17.10%. This is probably because of rapid urbanization and development in the neighboring cities.http://chandigarh.gov.in/cmp2031/demography.pdf According to the 2001 census, 79% people in Chandigarh are Hindus, 16% are Sikhs and minorities are Muslims, Christians, Buddhists and Jains. http://chandigarh.gov.in/knowchd_stat_ab07.asp ==Economy== [[File:Palace of Assembly Chandigarh 2006.jpg|thumb|Legislative Assembly by [[Le Corbusier]]]] [[File:Capitol High Court.jpg|thumb|[[Punjab and Haryana High Court]] by [[Le Corbusier]]]] Chandigarh has been rated as the “Wealthiest Town” of India.Chandigarh has been rated as the “Wealthiest Town” of India.http://chandigarh.gov.in/knowchd_redfinechd.htm The RBI ranked Chandigarh as the twelfth largest deposit centre and tenth largest credit centre nationwide as of June 2012. The government is a major employer in Chandigarh with three governments having their base here. A significant percentage of Chandigarh’s population therefore consists of people who are either working for one of these governments or have retired from government service. For this reason, Chandigarh is often called a "Pensioner's Paradise".[https://www.facebook.com/IASOURDREAM/posts/327185860650096 "Chandigarh is also called the Pensioner's Paradise"] Ordnance Cable Factory of the [[Ordnance Factories Board]] has been set up by the [[Government of India]]. There are about 15 medium to large industries including two in the Public sector. In addition Chandigarh has over 2500 units registered under small-scale sector. The important industries are paper manufacturing, basic metals and alloys and machinery. Other industries are relating to food products, sanitary ware, auto parts, machine tools, pharmaceuticals and electrical appliances. Yet, with a per capita income of [[File:Indian Rupee symbol.svg|8px]] 99,262, Chandigarh is the richest city in India.[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/chandigarhs-the-richest-of-em-all/12571-3.html Chandigarh's the richest of 'em all] Chandigarh's gross state domestic product for 2004 is estimated at $2.2 billion in current prices. Chandigarh ranks first in India in the Human Development Index, quality of life and e-readiness. The main occupation here is trade and business.[http://www.discoveredindia.com/chandigarh/chandigarh-the-fort-of-chandi/people.htm Occupation in Chandigarh]. The people of Chandigarh and their occupation.[http://www.bharatonline.com/chandigarh/culture/people.html Chandigarh people, culture and occupation]. The culture and people of Chandigarh. However, the [[Punjab and Haryana High Court]], [[Post Graduate Institute of Medical Education and Research|Post Graduate Institute of Medical Education and Research (PGIMER)]], the availability of an IT Park and more than a hundred of government schools provide job opportunity to people. Three major trade promotion organisations have their offices in Chandigarh. These are: Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce & Industry, (FICCI) the PHD Chamber of Commerce and Industry (PHDCCI) and the [[Confederation of Indian Industry]] (CII) which has its regional headquarters at Sector 31, Chandigarh.[http://www.cii.in/Regionpage.aspx?enc=eGTdm5V5nAehji8uvc8r9/JOHwrfX+fmCQ6xKZRBJcwNfHPk1Y9MV9guXPcPQiwD CII (NR) headquarters are at Chandigarh]. (Confederation of Indian Industry) The headquarters of CII North Region are at Chandigarh.[http://www.cii.in/PhotoGalleryDetail.aspx?enc=aF7Ur01v+lR+C3X7MEd6q43EP4jDEa8VyWF7gZWJTEZTnhat3zcTk5sdSthQYEraUBk12qf6dekhGj3QR5WYiGwaexJkILWGl7uUYya3Uhx+t3qymrqpLVQiYHjQTnL0vehBPvqeM8P9mAdCrMscGg== Confederation of Indian Industry]. The Headquarters of CII (NR) are at Chandigarh. Chandigarh IT Park (also known as Rajiv Gandhi Chandigarh Technology Park) is the city's attempt to break into the [[information technology]] world. Chandigarh's infrastructure, proximity to [[Delhi]], Haryana, Punjab and [[Himachal Pradesh]], and the IT talent pool attracts IT businesses looking for office space in the area. Major Indian firms and multinational corporations like [[Quark, Inc.|Quark]], [[Infosys]], [[Dell, Inc.|Dell]], [[IBM, Inc.|IBM]], [[TechMahindra]], have set up base in the city and its suburbs. According to a 2014 survey, Chandigarh is ranked 9th in the top 50 cities identified globally as "emerging outsourcing and IT services destinations" ahead of cities like Beijing.[http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2007/10/03/stories/2007100351450400.htm The Hindu Business Line] ==Politics== {{Main|Chandigarh (Lok Sabha constituency)}} {{Multiple image |align=right |direction=vertical |image1=PawanKumarBansalChd.JPG |caption1=Pawan Kumar Bansal, who was elected three times in a row from Chandigarh constituency in General Elections. |image2=Kiron kher colors indian telly awards.jpg |caption2=Kirron Kher is the current Member of Parliament elected from Chandigarh. }} Chandigarh, being a [[Union Territory]] is not entitled to a state-level election, thus [[State Assembly elections in India|State Assembly elections]] are not held here and it is directly controlled by the [[Central government]]. The mayor and Councillors of Chandigarh. Retrieved December 2014. ==Places of interest== [[File:Chandigarh Lake.jpg|left|thumb|Sukhna Lake]] Chandigarh has various visitor attractions including theme gardens within the city. Some notable sites are:{{cite web |url= http://chandigarhtourism.gov.in/Chandigarh%20Tourism%20-%20places%20to%20see.htm|title= Places to See|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= chandigarhtourism.gov.in |publisher=Chandigarh Tourism |accessdate=19 March 2014}} ===Sukhna Lake=== [[Sukhna Lake]] is associated in Sector 1, adjoining the [[Rock Garden of Chandigarh|Rock Garden]] near the foothills of the Shivalik.[http://www.ixigo.com/sukhna-lake-chandigarh-india-location-address-situated-map-ne-1282011 Location of Sukhna in Chandigarh] This is the exact address where Sukhna is located. Sukhna is an artificial lake. This 3 km rain-fed lake was created in 1958 by damming the Sukhna Choe, a seasonal stream coming down from the Shivalik Hills.[http://www.chandigarh.co.uk/tourist-attractions/sukhna-lake.html About Sukhna Lake] How was Sukhna made and when? It has [[The Garden of Silence]] within it.[https://kiboli.wordpress.com/2012/07/05/chandigarh-the-city-beautiful/img_2821/ Garden of Silence is inside Sukhna] The location of Garden of Silence is in Sukhna itself. The atmosphere here is serene. Sukhna Lake is the venue for many festive celebrations. The most popular is the Mango Festival held during the [[monsoons]]. It is believed that a Swiss architect [[Pierre Jeanneret]]'s ashes were immersed in this lake according to his will as he developed a deep bond with the lake.[http://www.helmutt.be/library/pierre-jeanneret/ Pierre Jeanneret's biography] One of the architects of Chandigarh was attached to Sukhna.[http://eronjohnsonantiques.com/pages/biography-pierre-jeanneret About Pierre Jeanneret] The Swiss architect's biography who designed some of Chandigarh.[http://www.librairie7l.com/le-corbusier-pierre-jeanneret-chandigarh-india-collectif-book.php Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret] Pierre's ashes were immersed in Sukhna. [[File:Chand2.jpg|280px|thumbnail|right|The garden is most famous for its sculptures made from recycled ceramic, Rock Garden]] ===Rock Garden=== The [[Rock Garden of Chandigarh|Rock Garden]] is situated in the middle of the Capitol Complex and the [[Sukhna Lake]] in Sector 1.[http://nekchand.com/about-the-garden Location of Rock Garden] The Garden is associated adjoining Sukhna Lake. It is also known as [[Nek Chand]] Rock Garden after its founder.[http://nekchand.com/about-nek-chand-2 About Rock Garden] Retrieved from official website of Nek Chand. It has numerous sculptures made by using a variety of different discarded waste materials like frames, mudguards, forks, handle bars, metal wires, play marbles, porcelain, auto parts, broken bangles etc.[http://www.chandigarh.co.uk/tourist-attractions/rock-garden.html How was Rock Garden made?] The way how Nek Chand got the idea to make the famous garden. It is believed that Nek Chand himself went up the Shivalik hills and got different stones and materials with which he started designing the garden.[http://citcochandigarh.gov.in/places_to_visit/rock_garden.html Rock Garden - Places to visit in Chandigarh] Nek Chand got stones himself. [[File:Rose Garden Chandigarh India (2).jpg|thumb|left|225px|The Rose Garden]] ===Rose Garden=== [[Zakir Hussain Rose Garden]], or simply Rose Garden, is named after the former President of India, Zakir Hussain. It is situated in Sector 16.[http://www.ixigo.com/zakir-hussain-rose-garden-chandigarh-india-ne-1273751 Location of Rose Garden] The Rose Garden is situated in Sector 16, Chandigarh. The garden is known to be the greatest of its types in [[Asia]].[http://chandigarhtourism.gov.in/Chandigarh%20Tourism%20-%20places%20to%20see-rose_garden.htm] Largest rose garden in Asia (Retrieved from official website of Chandigarh Tourism). The garden is said to be spread about thirty to forty acres containing nearly 825 varieties of roses in it and more than 32,500 varieties of other medicinal plants and trees.[http://www.mapsofindia.com/chandigarh/rose-garden.html About Rose Garden] The trees and plants in Rose Garden. {{Multiple image |align=right |direction=vertical |image1=Arch Museum 46.JPG |caption1=Government Museum & Art Gallery |image2=Musical Fountain, Sector 17, Chandigarh.jpg |caption2=Musical Fountain, Sector 17, Chandigarh |image3=Le Corbusier Centre, Sector 19.jpg |caption3=Le Corbusier Centre, Sector 19 |image4=Valley_of_Animals.jpg |caption4=The entrance to Valley of Animals, Sector 49 in Chandigarh. }} ===Leisure Valley=== A continuum of various theme gardens, Leisure Valley is a linear park over 8 km long which starts from Sector 1 in the north and leaves Chandigarh at its southern most edge. It consists of many theme parks, botanical gardens and green belts.[http://chandigarh.gov.in/green_leisure.htm Gardens and parks in Chandigarh] Chandigarh has a straight row of parks from the North to the South end. ===Other destinations=== Other tourist destinations include The New Lake in Sector 42, Capitol Complex in Sector 1, City Centre in Sector 17, [[Open Hand Monument|Open hand monument]] in Sector 1, Le Corbusier Centre in Sector 19, [[Government Museum and Art Gallery, Chandigarh|Government Museum and Art Gallery]] in Sector 10, International Doll Museum in Sector 23. There are many tourist gardens like the Garden of Fragrance in Sector 36, Butterfly Park in Sector 23, Valley of Animals in Sector 49, the Japanese Garden in Sector 31 and the Terraced Garden in Sector 33. Several other famous tourist destinations like [[Pinjore Gardens]], [[Morni Hills]], [[Nada Sahib]], [[Kasauli]] lie in its vicinity. ==Proposals== Many projects have been proposed by the Chandigarh Administration. Some of them are: * [[Chandigarh Metro]]: It is likely to start by the year 2018 with estimated cost of around 10,900 [[crore]]s including 50% funds from the governments of Punjab and Haryana and 25% from Chandigarh and Government of India. Funds from the Japan government will include approximately 56% of the cost.http://chandigarhmetro.com/chandigarh-metro-project-cost-and-other-details/http://chandigarhmetro.com/ * [http://wikimapia.org/29873258/Proposed-Film-City Film City]: As a [[Member of parliament]] from Chandigarh and having connection with the film industry, [[Kirron Kher]] promised a film city for Chandigarh. After winning the seat, she said that she had difficulty in acquiring land in Chandigarh.http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/trying-to-get-film-city-for-chandigarh-soon-kirron-kher-114082500941_1.html However, her proposal was accepted by the Chandigarh Administration and the film city is proposed to be set up in Sarangpur, Chandigarh.http://chandigarh.gov.in/admn_new_init_filmcity.htm ==Education== {{See also|List of educational institutions in Chandigarh}} [[File:Gandhi Bhawan at Punjab University.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Gandhi Bhawan, Chandigarh|Gandhi Bhavan]] built by [[Pierre Jeanneret]] for [[Panjab University]]]] There are numerous education institutions in Chandigarh. These range from privately and publicly operated schools to colleges and the [[Panjab University]]. Other Institutions are [[Post Graduate Institute of Medical Education and Research]] (PGIMER), Govt Medical college & Hospital, Punjab Engineering College Deemed University, Govt College for Men, Govt College for Women, DAV College, [http://www.mcmdavcw-chd.edu/ MCM DAV College for Women], [http://sggscollege.ac.in/ Sri Guru Gobind Singh Khalsa College-26], Govt Homeopathic College, Ayurvedic College, Govt Polytechnical College, Govt Home Science College, Dr Ambedkar Institute of Hotel management etc. These institutions are a large draw for students from around the world.{{cite news|title=City Beautiful|url=http://www.indianbackpacker.com/index.php/india/north/chandigarh-city-beautiful|accessdate=2 January 2013|newspaper=The Indian Backpacker|date=December 2012}} According to Chandigarh administration's department of education, there are a total of 107 government schools in Chandigarh and convent schools like [[St. Anne's Convent School, Chandigarh|St. Anne's Convent School]], [[Carmel Convent School]] and [[St. Joseph Senior Secondary School, Chandigarh|St. Joseph Senior Secondary School]].{{cite web|title=Department of Education|url=http://www.chdeducation.gov.in/schoolslist.asp}} ==Transport== [[File:National Highway 21, India.jpg|thumbnail|The 8-lane national highway 21 road passing through Chandigarh.]] ===Road=== Chandigarh has the largest number of vehicles per capita in India.[http://www.mapsofindia.com/top-ten-cities-of-india/top-ten-highest-no-of-car-ownership.html Top Ten Towns with Highest Nos. of Car Ownership in India] Wide, well maintained roads and parking spaces all over the city ease local transport.http://citcochandigarh.com/places_to_visit/architecture/index.php The [[Chandigarh Transport Undertaking]] (CTU) operates public transport buses from its Inter State Bus Terminals (ISBT) in Sectors 17 and 43 of the city.[http://chdctu.gov.in/ISBT.aspx Chandigarh Transport Undertaking ISBT] CTU also operates frequent bus services to the neighbouring states of [[Punjab region|Punjab]], [[Haryana]], [[Himachal Pradesh]] and to [[Delhi]]. Chandigarh is well connected by road by [[National Highway 22 (India)|NH 22]] (Ambala - Kalka - [[Shimla]] - [[Khab]], Kinnaur) and [[National Highway 21 (India)|NH 21]] (Chandigarh - [[Manali, Himachal Pradesh|Manali]]).http://chandigarh.gov.in/cmp2031/traffic.pdf ===Rail=== [[Chandigarh railway station]] lies in the [[Northern Railway zone]] of the [[Indian Railway]] network and provide connectivity to major Indian cities like [[Delhi]], [[Mumbai]], [[Kolkata]], [[Visakhapatnam]], [[Jaipur]], [[Lucknow]], [[Bhopal]], [[Indore]], [[Trivandrum]] and [[Amritsar]]. It also links other cities like [[Ambala]], [[Kollam]], [[Panipat]] and [[Kalka]]. The [[Chandigarh Metro|Chandigarh Metro Rail]] is a proposed metro rail to serve the city locally and connect it to other two cities of the [[Chandigarh Tricity]]. It is expected to start working by 2018 along with the extension of [[Kolkata Metro]] and proposed [[Indore Metro]]. [[File:Chandigarh Airport - mural.jpg|thumbnail|Chandigarh airport from inside.]] ===Air=== [[Chandigarh Airport]] has scheduled commercial flights to major cities of India including [[Indira Gandhi International Airport|Delhi]], [[Chatrapati Shivaji International Airport|Mumbai]], [[Indore]], [[Jaipur]], [[Bangalore]] and [[Srinagar]]. Flights are available to [[Bhuntar Airport|Kullu-Manali]] also with Himalayan Bulls. A new international terminal is under construction. International flights are scheduled to ply from March 2015.http://indianexpress.com/article/cities/chandigarh/intl-terminal-may-be-operational-by-march-next-year/ ==Media== ===Newspapers=== Chandigarh has numerous [[Indian newspapers|newspaper]] publications, television and radio stations. The most famous languages for newspapers being [[English language|English]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]] and [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]]. Popular English newspapers are [[Hindustan Times]], [[The Times of India]], [[The Indian Express]] and [[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]. Hindi newspapers are also famous like [[Dainik Jagran]], [[Amar Ujala]], [[Dainik Bhaskar]], [[Punjab Kesari]] and [[Hindi language|Hindi]] edition of [[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]. Several [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] newspapers like [[Ajit (newspaper)|Ajit]] and [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] editions of other newspapers. Magazines like Brunch, Champak are published with these newspapers.http://www.justdial.com/chandigarh/Newspaper/ct-10337036 ===Television=== Numerous [[Television in India|Indian]] and international television channels can be watched in Chandigarh through one of the [[pay-tv|Pay TV]] companies or the local cable television provider. There are many news channels basically set-up in Chandigarh like [[News 24 (India)|News 24]], [[PTC Punjabi]].[http://www.livetv24.tv/. The Chandigarh page of News 24's website.]http://www.justdial.com/Chandigarh/News-Satellite-Channels/ct-10337028 ===Radio stations=== There are many radio stations in Chandigarh broadcasting on the [[Frequency modulation|FM]] band including Big FM, [[Vividh Bharati]] etc.http://trace.bharatiyamobile.com/Search_FM_Stations_City_List.php?location=Chandigarh ==Entertainment== ===Sports=== Chandigarh is home to numerous inter state sporting teams and other sporting franchises like [[Kings XI Punjab]] of the [[Indian Premier League]] (IPL). The [[Sector 16 Stadium]], owned by [[Haryana Cricket Association]], has been a venue of several international matches. But it has lost prominence after the [[PCA Stadium]] was constructed in Mohali. It still provides a platform for cricketers in this region to practice and play inter-state matches.[http://www.espncricinfo.com/india/content/ground/57993.html Sector 16 Stadium] The [[Chandigarh Golf Club]] has 7,202 yard, 18 hole course known for its challenging narrow fairways, a long 613 yard long, dogleg 7th hole and floodlighting on the first nine holes.[http://chandigarhgolfclub.golfgaga.com/ Chandigarh Golf Club (CGC)] There are many other sports grounds and complex like the Lake Sports Complex; Sports Complexes in Sectors 7, 42, 46; Table Tennis Hall, Sector 23; Hockey Centre, Sector 18; Football Centre, Sector 17; Skating Rink, Sector 10 and so on. Many personalities from this region have excelled in sports.[http://chandigarh.gov.in/dept_sports.htm Sports department of Chandigarh Administration] ===Gardens=== It also has two gardens of international repute – the [[Rock Garden of Chandigarh]] in sector 1 and the [[Zakir Hussain Rose Garden]] in sector 16. The latter has the distinction of being the largest of its kind in Asia. Chandigarh has a belt of parks running from Sector to Sector. It is known for its green belts in most of the sectors and other special tourist parks.[http://stylesatlife.com/articles/parks-in-chandigarh/ Parks in Chandigarh] ===Communications=== Available internet providers in Chandigarh are: [[Bharti Airtel]], Connect Broadband, Tata photon & 3G wireless internet, BSNL broadband, [[Reliance Communications|Reliance]] DSL and [[Bharti Airtel|Airtel]] 4G wifi among others.
